X1: Appropriations Act Forbidding Further National Forests: Debates and Proceedings. Excerpted from the Congressional Record: Containing the Proceedings and Debates of the Fifty-Ninth Congress, Second Session.  Volume XLI.  Pp. 1559, 1589, 1897-20, 2004, 2834, 2953-60, 3182-3207, 3281-3300, 3512, 3514-47, 3604-21, 3627-43, 3646-47, 3717-26, 3865-66, 3869-88, 3975, 3997, 4325-26, 4481-94, 4530-31, 4545, 4570, 4630-31.
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1907
X3: SUMMARY Procedure and debate surrounding the passage of H.R. 24815, which eventually became "An Act Making appropriations for the Department of Agriculture for the fiscal year ending June thirtieth, nineteen hundred and eight."  Sub-section, "Forest Service"  (34 Stat. 1269), in the Second Session of the 59th Congress.  The entire Agriculture Appropriations bill was discussed section by section by both the House and the Senate.  Several portions of the bill were controversial and the debate was lengthy.  In the debate on the Forest section issues of concern were whether or not permanent appropriations were a good idea; what the salary ranges for professional employees and political appointees in the department ought to be; the proper course of management for the national forests and the powers of the Secretary of Agriculture; the role of forests in protecting watersheds and in irrigation; the respective rights of the Federal government, the states, and individual property owners in the western lands; and whether homesteading in forest reserves was permissible.  The main point of the bill for forest conservation was that it renamed the forest reserves as national forests and that no more national forests could be created or enlarged in the West except by Act of Congress.
X4: NOTESWidely scattered pages selected from the complete record.  These pages report the report back from the House Committee on Agriculture by Representative Wadsworth (H.R. Report 6597), debate in the House, amendment and passage in the House, referral to the Senate Committee on Agriculture and Forestry, report back to the Senate with amendments (S. Report 6829), debate in the Senate, amendment and passage in the Senate, appointment of conference committee, conference report made, debate of conference report in the House, second conference appointed, agreement to conference report, signing by the Speaker of the House and the Vice President.  The signing by President Roosevelt is omitted in the Congressional Record.

X1: Forest Reserve Act: Debates and Proceedings. Excerpted from the Congressional Record: Containing the Proceedings and Debates of the Fifty-First Congress, First Session.  Also Special Session of the Senate.  Volume XXI.  Pp. 1523, 2349-53, 2533-34, 2537-39, 5272, 10031, 10085-94, 10454-55, 10760.
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1889
X3: SUMMARY Procedure and debate surrounding the early stages of the passage of H.R. 7254, which eventually became "An act to repeal timber-culture laws, and for other purposes" (26 Stat. 1095), known as the Forest Reserve Act, in the First Session of the 51st Congress.  Debate, which was lengthy and sometimes acrimonious, centered in the House on the reason for the proposed repeal of the Timber Culture Act, namely (in the words of Congressman Holman of Indiana) its abuse as "a source of dishonesty and fraud from the beginning," and whether or not this bill could best replace it by encouraging forestation; in the Senate, it also concerned the degree to which timber-cutting for private profit should be permitted on the public lands, and entailed the articulation of conservationist principles, explicit recognition of the link between forests and water conservation, and expressions of resentment by Senator Sanders of Montana toward Federal interference in the use of public resources by local citizens; the Senate also debated the possible impact of the bill on selected Native communities in Alaska.  Transcripts of debate include the presentation of brief Memorials from the American Forestry Association and from the Legislature of the State of Washington, which were entered into the record.
X4: NOTESWidely-scattered pages selected from a much longer document.  These pages reflect the bill's introduction by Congressman Payson, its reading, debate and passage in the House, the bill's report to the Senate and referral to the Senate Committee on Public Lands, its report back from the Committee with an amendment, extensive debate in the Senate, passage by the Senatte in amended form, the appointment of Senators to a House-Senate conference committee, the House's referral of the bill as amended by the Senate to the House Committee on Public Lands, and the House's agreement to a conference on the bill to resolve differences in the House and Senate versions.

Mann of Ilinois, Representative William S. Cowherd of Missouri, Representative Oscar W. Underwood of Alabama, Representative Joseph E. Ransdell of Louisiana, Representative William A. Reeder of Kansas, Representative Wesley L. Jones of Washington, Representative Eben W. Martin of South Dakota, Representative Charles Q. Tirrel of Massachusetts, Representative Thomas H. Tongue of Oregon, Representative John F. Shafroth of Colorado, Representative David H. Mercer of Nebraska, Representative J.C. Needham of California, and Representative George E. Sutherland of Utah.  The press interviews were with James J. Hill, Thomas F. Walsh (President of the National Irrigation Assciation), and Col. H.M. Chittenden of the U.S. Engineer Corps. Debate in the House centered on the urgency of the need for bird protection, the changing ethics of sport hunters (the bill had the support of the League of American Sportsmen, and Lacey himself expressed confidence that "to-day there is no friend that the birds have like the true sportsman...  The game hog' is an animal on two legs that is disappearing"), and the bill's potential for creating State/Federal and interstate jurisdictional conflicts; there was no debate in the Senate.

Debate concerned the Secretary of the Interior's regulation of grazing in the National Parks, and whether or not National Monuments in National Forests should remain under the jurisdiction of the Department of Agriculture; it also concerned budgetary questions and the prospect of bureaucratic growth.  The Senate wished to prohibit grazing, the House to permit it; the result was a compromise which permitted the Secretary of the Interior to regulate grazing except in Yellowstone National Park, where it was forbidden.

The report includes the text of H.R. 15522, and presents the arguments for its passage, notably the need for a park service separate from the Forest Service because the national parks are devoted to "the preservation of nature as it exists," whereas the national forests have "as primary objects and purposes the utilitarian use of land, of water, and of timber."  Also includes statistics on the number of visitors to each national park, 1908 to 1915, and correspondence in favor of the establishment of a national park service from Secretary of the Interior Franklin K. Lane and Secretary of Agriculture D.F. Houston.

X1: Newlands Reclamation Act: Debates and Proceedings. Excerpted from the Congressional Record: Containing the Proceedings and Debates of the Fifty-Seventh Congress, First Session.  Volume XXXV.  Pp. 813, 1047, 1383-86, 2134, 2218-24, 2276-85, 2380-81, 3812, 6669-6708, 6722-79, 6794, 6892, 6895, 6977, and Appendix pp. 253-65, 455-56, 496-98, 645-51.
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1902
X3: SUMMARY Procedure and debate surrounding the passage of S. 3057, which eventually became "An Act Appropriating the receipts from the sale and disposal of public lands in certain States and Territories to the construction of irrigation works for the reclamation of arid lands" (32 Stat. 388), in the First Session of the 57th Congress.  This is commonly known as the Newlands Reclamation Act.  The bill was a controversal one and debate was fierce and contentious, particularly in the House.  The principal issues were the constitutional one of the powers of the Federal government and under which clause of the Constitution was the bill lawful, and the related issue of the respective rights of the states and the Federal government, and the question of whether the irrigation of the arid West would help or harm the existing farming states.  One can find in the debate indications of regional tensions--both north-south and east-west--and of political tensions between and within parties.  There were objections to the powers given the Secretary of the Interior and to allowing one state's water to be used by another.  This legislation is thus a landmark both in conservation and water isssues and in the history of the changes in relations among the states and between the states and the Federal government.
X4: NOTESWidely-scattered pages selected from the complete record.  These pages report the bill's introduction by Senator Hansbrough and its referral to the Committee on Public Lands, its report back to the Senate (S. Report 254), debate in the Senate, amendment and passage in the Senate, referral to House Committee on Irrigation of Arid Lands, report back with amendment (H.R. Hilgard, C.E. Bessey, and William Saunders), urging that all timber lands in the hands of the U.S. government be withdrawn from sale pending review and revision of government policies so that timber lands may be permanently protected and properly administered. X1: Raker Act (Hetch Hetchy Act): Debates and Proceedings. Excerpted from the Congressional Record: Containing the Proceedings and Debates of the Sixty-Third Congress, First Session.  Volume L. X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1913
X3: SUMMARY Procedure and debate surrounding the passage of H.R. 7207, which eventually became "An Act Granting to the city and county of San Francisco certain rights of way in, over, and through certain public lands, the Yosemite National Park, and Stanislaus National Forest, and certain lands in the Yosemite National Park, the Stanislaus National Forest, and the public lands in the State of California, and for other purposes"  (38 Stat. 242), in the First Session of the 63rd Congress.  Debate was lengthy and complicated, involving many of the same issues that had come up in debate on earlier conservation legislation, such as the weighing of states' rights and the rights of the Federal government, and whether the use of natural resources should be free or taxed.  Debate in the House opened with the question of whether this was emergency legislation and continued with minute discussions over wording as well as broad disagreements of principle.  Each side introduced statements from its partisans, such as Secretary of the Interior Franklin K. Lane and Gifford Pinchot for those to whom "the highest form of conservation is the kind which conserves for human necessities and human rights" (Rep. Graham, p.3899) and John Muir and Robert Underwood Johnson for those who wished to preserve "this beautiful mountain gem" (Rep. Steenerson, p.3974).
X4: NOTESWidely scattered pages selected from the complete record.  These pages report the introduction of the bill by Representative Raker and its referral to the House Committee on the Public Lands, its report back to the House (H.R. Report 41), debate in the House, amendment and passage in the House, referral to the Senate Committee on Public Lands, report back to the Senate (S. Report 113), debate in the Senate, agreement to unanimous-consent agreement for vote in the Senate.

X3: SUMMARY Procedure and debate surrounding the passage of H.R. 7207, which eventually became "An Act Granting to the city and county of San Francisco certain rights of way in, over, and through certain public lands, the Yosemite National Park, and Stanislaus National Forest, and certain lands in the Yosemite National Park, the Stanislaus National Forest, and the public lands in the State of California, and for other purposes"  (38 Stat. 242), in the Second Session of the 63rd Congress.  Debate resumed in the Senate on the first day of the Second Session.  Themes raised in the House debate and earlier in the Senate were discussed again, including whether San Francisco really needed this water supply, the differing claims to use of the Hetch Hetchy water, whether the use of natural resources on public lands should be free or not, and the opposition to flooding the valley.  The number of letters in opposition to the bill entered in the Record attests to the wide-spread movement to defeat it.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 12, Chap. 43, p. 369.  "An Act for a joint Commission for the Preservation of the Atlantic Fisheries."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : Massachusetts : Boston Little, Brown and Company 1862 03 15
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes the President to appoint a commissioner to a joint U.S.-British-French commission "to frame measures to protect the fisheries off the coast of Newfoundland and North America against deterioration and destruction by means of set lines on the spawn banks, and like destructive practices."
X4: NOTESAn early example of national and international concern for the conservation of marine resources.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 13, Chap. 184, p. 325.  "An Act authorizing a Grant to the State of California of the Yo-Semite Valley,' and of the Land embracing the Mariposa Big Tree Grove.'" [S. 203; Public Act No. 159]
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : Massachusetts : Boston Little, Brown and Company 1864 06 30
X3: SUMMARY Grants Yosemite Valley and Mariposa Big Tree Grove to California "upon the express conditions that the premises shall be held for public use, resort, and recreation."
X4: NOTESThis precedent-setting legislation, introduced at the request of a group of wealthy but historically elusive Californians (and quite possibly also at the instigation of landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted), establishes the nation's first public park created for the protection of scenic beauty, albeit by a grant to a state.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 16, Chap. 189, pp. 180-182.  "An Act to prevent the Extermination of Fur-bearing Animals in Alaska."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : Massachusetts : Boston Little, Brown, and Company 1870 07 01
X3: SUMMARY Restricts hunting of Alaskan fur seals.
X4: NOTESAn early attempt at wildlife conservation for economic purposes; in the next several decades, Congress and the President made repeated efforts to resolve the complex local, regional and international issues affecting what was seen as an important wildlife resource.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 16, Resolution No. 22, pp. 593-94.  "Joint Resolution for the Protection and Preservation of the Food Fishes of the Coast of the United States."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : Massachusetts : Boston Little, Brown, and Company 1871 02 09
X3: SUMMARY Joint Congressional Resolution noting that "the most valuable food fishes of the coast and the lakes of the United States are rapidly diminishing in number," and authorizing the President to appoint a commissioner of fish and fisheries to investigate the causes of the problem and recommend appropriate remedial measures to Congress.
X4: NOTESRepresents recognition of the need for conservation of certain economically important biological resources.  This Resolution established the Commission of Fish and Fisheries, which later became the Bureau of Fisheries of the Department of Commerce.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 17, Chap. 24, pp. 32-33.  "An Act to set apart a certain Tract of Land lying near the Head-waters of the Yellowstone River as a public Park." [S. 392]
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : Massachusetts : Boston Little, Brown and Company 1872 03 01
X3: SUMMARY This Act designates Yellowstone as a park "for the benefit and enjoyment of the people," with "all timber, mineral deposits, natural curiosities, or wonders" within it to be retained "in their natural condition," though roads, bridle-paths, and buildings for the accomodation of visitors may be permitted.  Jurisdiction is given to the Secretary of Interior.
X4: NOTESThis landmark legislation creates the first national park.  The painter and explorer George Catlin had proposed the idea that Western prairies might be preserved as "a nation's Park" in 1832, the same year that Congress set aside the medicinal springs of Hot Springs, Arkansas, as a public reservation (the area became a national park in 1921), and the 1864 Congressional grant of Yosemite to California (13 Stat. 325) had set an important legislative precedent.  Nevertheless, the implementation of the national park idea in this Act must be considered a conservation milestone of global significance.  The bill's immediate origins are shadowy and open to dispute (explorer and subsequent Park Superintendent Nathaniel P. Langford's well-known claim that the idea originated around a Yellowstone-area campfire in 1870 is almost certainly an ex post facto legend), but the success of the measure in Congress was indisputably due to recognition of the area's great commercial potential as a magnet for tourism--the bill was pressed by representatives of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company, which stood to profit handsomely--as well as its demonstrable dearth of other exploitable natural resources.  The photographs of William Henry Jackson and the paintings of Thomas Moran, both from the Hayden Expedition of 1871, provided Congress with powerfully persuasive images of the region as a place of uniquely American wonders.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 17, Chap. 277, pp. 605-06.  "An Act to encourage the Growth of Timber on western Prairies." [S. 680; Public Act No. 105]
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : Massachusetts : Boston Little, Brown, and Company 1873 03 03
X3: SUMMARY This Act grants a "quarter-section" (160 acres) of land to any settler who has cultivated trees on 40 acres of it for ten years.
X4: NOTESKnown as the Timber Culture Act.  This pioneering effort by Congress to encourage private conservation proved ultimately unenforceable and subject to fraud; it was repealed by the Forest Reserve Act of 1891 (26 Stat. 1095).

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 18, Part 3, Chap. 151, pp. 481-82.  "An act to protect ornamental and other trees on Government reservations and on lands purchased by the United States, and for other purposes."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1875 03 03
X3: SUMMARY Forbids unlawful cutting or injury of timber, ornamental or shade trees on government property reserved or purchased for public use.
X4: NOTESReflects public concern for the aesthetic value of trees at a time before scientific forest management had come to the fore in public policy, as well as concern for conservation of a public resource.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 19, Chap. 107, p. 377.  "An act to provide for the sale of desert lands in certain States and Territories--"
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1877 03 03
X3: SUMMARY Grants up to one section--640 acres--of public desert land in California, Oregon, Nevada, Washington, Idaho, Montana, Utah, Wyoming, Arizona, New Mexico, and "Dakota" to any citizen at a total cost of $1.25 per acre on condition that the claimant demonstrate "reclamation" of the land by irrigation, for which purpose the use of water from other public lands is free.
X4: NOTESKnown as the Desert Land Act.  Although not usually considered an aspect of conservation in our own time, the use and management of water resources was intimately related to other aspects of conservation policy--particularly land use and forestry--in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.  This Act was an attempt to encourage private irrigation initiatives, though its provisions proved all too susceptible to corrupt manipulation; by the turn of the century, the Federal government itself initiated a systematic and aggressive program of water resource management.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 19, Chap. 287, pp. 166-67.  "Department of Agriculture."  Sub-section of "An act making appropriations for the legislative, executive, and judicial expenses of the Government for the year ending June thirtieth, eighteen hundred and seventy-seven, and for other purposes."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1876 08 15
X3: SUMMARY This sub-section of a longer appropriations bill contains a paragraph which sets aside $2,000 for "some man of approved attainments," to be selected by the Commissioner of Agriculture, "to prosecute investigations and inqueries [sic], with the view of ascertaining the annual amount of consumption, importation, and exportation of timber and other forest-products, the probable supply for future wants, the means best adapted to their preservation and renewal, the influence of forests upon climate, and the measures that have been successfully applied in foreign countries, or that may be deemed applicable in this country, for the preservation and restoration or planting of forests," and to prepare a report on these matters for Congress.
X4: NOTESThis measure establishes the position of federal forestry agent, and signals the beginning of active Federal involvement in forestry.  Its origins lay in a paper read by Franklin B. Hough at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in 1873, "On the Duty of Governments in the Preservation of Forests;" the Association thereupon embarked on an effort to persuade Congress to begin to address forest preservation issues, and this measure was the eventual result.  Hough himself was appointed the first federal forestry agent.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 20, Chap. 182, pp. 394-95.  "Geological Survey."  Sub-section of "An act making appropriations for sundry civil expenses of the government for the fiscal year ending June thirtieth, eighteen hundred and eighty, and for other purposes."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1879 03 03
X3: SUMMARY Establishes the Geological Survey, within the Interior Department, with responsibility for "the classification of the public lands" according to physical characteristics and resources, "examination of the Geological Structure, mineral resources and products of the national domain," and preparation of reports and maps.
X4: NOTESAn indication of the increasing public concern with the rational management of natural resources.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 20, Chap. 213, pp. 134-135.  "An act for the preservation of game and protection of birds in the District of Columbia."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia  Washington Government Printing Office 1878 06 15
X3: SUMMARY Establishes hunting regulations for the District of Columbia.
X4: NOTESThe existence of these sorts of regulations indicates Congress's recognition of the need for bird and game conservation in the local jurisdiction for which it was responsible; in general, state-level regulation anticipated Federal efforts in this area.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 23, Chap. 316, p. 340.  "An act to protect the fish in the Potomac River in the District of Columbia, and to provide a spawning-ground for shad and herring in the said Potomac River."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1885 03 02
X3: SUMMARY Forbids the use of certain kinds of nets and other fishing devices in the Potomac, and outlaws the flow or deposit into the Potomac or Rock Creek in the District of "any tar, oil, ammoniacal liquor or other waste products of any gas-works or of works engaged in using such products or any waste product whatever of any mechanical, chemical, manufacturing or refining establishment."
X4: NOTESEssentially a local law, passed by Congress by virtue of its jurisdiction over the District of Columbia, this Act reflects concern over freshwater fish conservation and industrial water pollution.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 24, Chap. 209, pp. 408-09.  "An act to grant certain Seal Rocks to the city and county of San Francisco, State of California, in trust for the people of the United States." [S. 2428; Public Act No. 67]
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1887 02 23
X3: SUMMARY Grants the Seal Rocks off Point Lobos in trust to San Francisco for the people of the United States, on condition that San Francisco "shall keep said rocks free from encroachment by man, and shall preserve from molestation the seals and other animals now accustomed to resort there, to the end that said Seal Rocks will continue to be a public preserve and resort for seals."
X4: NOTESAn early example of Congressional wildlife protection legislation; accomplished by means of a grant to a local authority.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 24, Chap. 288, pp. 434-35.  "An act relating to the importing and landing of mackerel caught during the spawning season."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1887 02 28
X3: SUMMARY Outlaws importation and landing of mackerel other than Spanish mackerel caught during the March-June spawning season for a five-year period (1888-1893).
X4: NOTESAn example of marine resources conservation legislation.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 24, Chap. 575, pp. 100-104.  "An Act making an appropriation for the Department of Agriculture for the fiscal year ending June thirtieth, eighteen hundred and eighty-seven, and for other purposes."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1886 06 30
X3: SUMMARY This appropriations bill contains two elements of special relevance for conservation history: first, a paragraph entitled "Division of Economic Ornithology and Mammalogy" (p. 101), which creates the Division and charges it with "the promotion of economic ornithology and mammalogy; [and] an investigation of the food-habits, distribution, and migrations of North American birds and mammals in relation to agriculture, horticulture and forestry;" and second, a paragraph entitled "Division of Forestry" (p. 103), which gives the Division statutory permanence within the Department of Agriculture by an appropriation of $10,000.
X4: NOTESThe establishment of the Division of Economic Ornithology was a small but significant step towards involving the Federal government in wildlife study, management and protection.  In 1896, the Division was replaced by the Division (later Bureau) of Biological Survey (see 29 Stat. 99).  The formal establishment of the Division of Forestry was a key step in the development of the Federal government's role in forest conservation.  In 1901, the Division became the Bureau of Forestry (31 Stat 922); and in 1905, it became the U.S. Forest Service, with responsibility for the Federal forest reserves (see 33 Stat. 628 and 861).

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 25, Chap. 415, pp. 1009-1010.  "An act to provide for the protection of the salmon fisheries of Alaska."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1889 03 02
X3: SUMMARY Outlaws the construction of any impediment to the passage of salmon to their spawning grounds in Alaska; directs the Commissioner of Fish and Fisheries to recommend any additional legislation which may be necessary for protecting Alaskan salmon fisheries; and prohibits the killing of fur-bearing animals in the U.S. dominions of the Bering Sea.
X4: NOTESMarine conservation on the grounds of economic value.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 26, Chap. 1121, p. 502.  "An act to authorize entry of the public lands by incorporated cities and towns for cemetery and park purposes."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1890 09 30
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes incorporated cities and towns to purchase a portion of public lands within three miles of their limits for use as cemeteries and parks.
X4: NOTESReflects the era's concern with the importance of public parks as the nation became increasingly urban; the movement for the development of urban parks, like the associated growth of landscape architecture as a profession, arose from much the same cultural matrix as the preservationist approach to conservationism, a connection which is perhaps most obvious in the life and thought of Frederick Law Olmsted, Sr.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 26, Chap. 1263, pp. 650-52.  "An act to set apart certain tracts of land in the State of California as forest reservations." [H.R. 12187]
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1890 10 01
X3: SUMMARY Establishes the foundations of Yosemite National Park (in Sections 1 and 2 of the Act) and General Grant National Park (in Section 3), and adds lands to the park which became Sequoia National Park (also in Section 3), by setting aside certain tracts of land in California as forest reservations under the jurisdiction of the Secretary of the Interior, directing him to establish regulations to "provide for the preservation from injury of all timber, mineral deposits, natural curiosities, or wonders within said reservation[s], and their retention in their natural condition."
X4: NOTESThe historian Roderick B. Nash calls the result of this legislation the nation's "first preserve consciously designed to protect wilderness" (Wilderness and the American Mind [1967; 2nd ed. New Haven and London: Yale University Press, 1973], p. 132).  However, the language of the legislation associates it also with forestry efforts, demonstrating that the preservationist and utilitarian strands of conservation thought had not yet sharply separated, a fact which perhaps facilitated the legislation's passage.  Though preservationists such as John Muir and Century Magazine editor Robert Underwood Johnson had been pressing for Yosemite's establishment as a national park, it is here designated as "reserved forest lands," and it was Secretary of the Interior John W. Noble who decided to administer all of areas protected in this bill as parks (see Alfred Runte, National Parks: The American Experience [2nd ed., Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1987], pp. 58-63, for further details).

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 26, Chap. 561, pp. 1095-1103.  "An act to repeal timber-culture laws, and for other purposes." [H.R. 7254; Public Act No. 162]
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1891 03 03
X3: SUMMARY Repeals the Timber Culture Act of 1873, and authorizes the President to "set apart and reserve... as public reservations" forested portions of the public lands in any State or Territory.
X4: NOTESKnown as the Forest Reserve Act.  These reserves, and the President's authority to create them, established the foundation of the future National Forest system; in his autobiography Gifford Pinchot termed this Act "the most important legislation in the history of Forestry in America."  Recent historical investigations have demonstrated that the intent of the legislation was always mixed, anticipating both use and preservation, and that the key Congressional figure was almost certainly Representative William Steele Holman of Indiana, the probable author of Section 24.  The major incentive for forest conservation of this kind was concern for watershed protection, particularly the desire to prevent erosion and flooding by protecting forests at the headwaters and along the banks of rivers, as well as recognition of the need to protect and conserve the nation's timber supply, and to ensure the democratic development of timberlands by protecting them from exploitation by private wealth; however some, such as Secretary of the Interior John W. Noble, also saw forest reserves as a means to protect wildlife and areas of great natural beauty.  In crafting legislation for these purposes, Congress was responding to rising concerns for forest management expressed by scientists, as in the persistent efforts of the American Forestry Association and in the January, 1890 "Memorial of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in Behalf of a Proper Forest Policy;" as well as to the groundwork of sympathetic leadership laid by conservation-minded individuals within the Federal government, such as Division of Forestry chief Bernhard Fernow and Secretary Noble; and to the advocacy of sportsmen-conservationists, such as George Bird Grinnell in the pages of the magazine Forest and Stream.  Nevertheless, the revolutionary and potentially conflict-ridden nature of this new policy is implicitly reflected in the text of the Act, for Congress declines to provide policy guidelines or specifications for the forest reservations' management. (For the history of this legislation, see especially the essays in Harold K. Steen, ed., Origins of the National Forests: A Centennial Symposium [Durham, North Carolina: Forest History Society, 1992].)

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 26, Chap. 926, p. 478.  "An act to set apart a certain tract of land in the State of California as a public park." [H.R. 11570]
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1890 09 25
X3: SUMMARY Establishes what became Sequoia National Park by setting apart a tract of land in California "as a public park, or pleasure ground, for the benefit and enjoyment of the people," on the grounds that "the rapid destruction of timber and ornamental trees in various parts of the United States, some of which trees are the wonders of the world on account of their size and the limited number growing, makes it a matter of importance that at least some of said forests should be preserved."  The park's resources are therefore to be retained "in their natural condition," secure from injury.
X4: NOTESThis park was not named by Congress; it was named Sequoia National Park by Secretary of the Interior John W. Noble (see Alfred Runte, National Parks: The American Experience [2nd ed., Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1987], p. 279 n. 34).

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 26, Proclamation No. 1, pp. 1543-44.  "By the President of the United States of America.  A Proclamation."

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 26, Proclamation No. 17, p. 1565.  "By the President of the United States of America.  A Proclamation."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1891 03 30
X3: SUMMARY Sets aside a tract of land in Wyoming as a forest reservation.
X4: NOTESCreates the first of what became the national forests, known initially as the Yellowstone Park Timberland Reserve, on lands adjacent to the Park.  This Proclamation took advantage of the provisions of the Forest Reserve Act (26 Stat. 1095) to protect Yellowstone National Park, consummating a lengthy private campaign waged by individuals concerned about the Park, notably Arnold Hague of the U.S. Geological Survey.  The boundaries of this tract were further specified in a second Presidential proclamation, issued September 10, 1891 (27 Stat. 989); this was necessary because "some question has arisen as to the boundaries proclaimed being sufficiently definite to cover the forests intended to be reserved."

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 29, Resolution No. 58, pp. 475-76.  "Joint Resolution To authorize a scientific investigation of the fur-seal fisheries."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1896 06 08
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes a two-year scientific investigation of the fur-seal herds in the Northern Pacific Ocean and Bering Sea, and appropriates funds for the purpose.
X4: NOTESIn this instance, scientific investigation was motivated by concern for the situation of an economically valuable natural resource.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 30, Chap. 2, pp. 32-36.  "Surveying the Public Lands."  Sub-section of section entitled "Under the Department of the Interior," within "An Act Making appropriations for sundry civil expenses of the Government for the fiscal year ending June thirtieth, eighteen hundred and ninety-eight, and for other purposes."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1897 06 04
X3: SUMMARY Specifies that the purpose of forest reservations is "to improve and protect the forest within the reservation, or for... securing favorable conditions of water flows, and to furnish a continuous supply of timber for the use and necessities of citizens of the United States," and stipulates that the regulated harvesting of timber, mining of mineral resources, and use of water on forest reservations may be permitted by the Secretary of the Interior.
X4: NOTESKnown as the Forest Management Act, or Organic Act.  Illuminates Congress's understanding at this time that forest reservations were intended for managed use, not for wilderness preservation, and demonstrates lawmakers' recognition of the close connection between forest management and the management of other resources, especially water.  Note that the Act's provision that private owners be permitted to exchange lands within the reservations for equivalent lands outside proved open to fraud, enabling large timber companies and railroads to lumber their lands within the reservations and then exchange them for other timber holdings elsewhere.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 30, Chap. 221, p. 908.  "An Act To authorize the Secretary of the Interior to rent or lease certain portions of forest reserve."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1899 02 28
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to lease portions of forest reserves in the vicinity of mineral or medicinal springs "where the public is accustomed or desires to frequent, for health or pleasure" so that sanitariums or hotels may be built for public use.
X4: NOTESAn early indication of recreational demands on forest reserves; suggests the multiple uses deemed appropriate for these reserves.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 30, Chap. 223, pp. 910-11.  "An Act To grant to the Pasadena and Mount Wilson Railway Company right of way and certain lands for railroad purposes through the San Gabriel Forest Reserve."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1899 02 28
X3: SUMMARY Grants a railroad right of way through the San Gabriel Forest Reserve in California, and authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to sell several tracts of land to the railroad.
X4: NOTESDemonstrates the paramount importance of utilitarian considerations in the public management of natural resources.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 30, Chap. 228, pp. 915-916.  "An Act Granting to the City of Boulder, in the State of Colorado, certain lands for park purposes and for the preservation of the native trees on said lands, and for other purposes."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1899 02 28
X3: SUMMARY Grants land to the city of Boulder, Colorado, for a park, with the stipulation that the city must "as far as practicable, protect and preserve all the native trees now growing on said lands, and protect other trees thereon."
X4: NOTESReflects aesthetic and other non-utilitarian concerns for the value of trees, and exemplifies the movement to create municipal parks which flourished in this era; one of a number of similar Congressional grants made before the 1920s.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 30, Chap. 3, pp. 226-27.  "An Act Prohibiting the killing of fur seals in the waters of the North Pacific Ocean."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1897 12 29
X3: SUMMARY Prohibits the killing, capturing, or hunting of fur seals in the northern Pacific Ocean "at any time or in any manner whatever."
X4: NOTESReflects continuing concern over protection of an economically valuable resource.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 30, Chap. 338, pp. 415-16.  "An Act For the protection of fish in the District of Columbia, for the maintenance of a permanent spawning ground in the Potomac River in said District, and for other purposes."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1898 05 17
X3: SUMMARY Forbids the use of certain kinds of nets and other fishing devices in the Potomac; regulates the seasons for bass, herring, shad, and other fish; and outlaws the flow or deposit into the Potomac or Rock Creek in the District of "any tar, oil, ammoniacal liquor or other waste products of any gas-works or works engaged in using such products, or any waste product whatever of any mechanical, chemical, manufacturing or refining establishment."
X4: NOTESEssentially a local law, passed by Congress by virtue of its jurisdiction over the District of Columbia; reflects concern over freshwater fish conservation and industrial water pollution.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 30, Chap. 343, p. 418.  "An Act Granting to the Santa Fe and Grand Canyon Railroad Company right of way for railroad purposes through the Grand Canyon Forest Reserve in northern Arizona."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1898 05 18
X3: SUMMARY Grants a railroad right of way through the Grand Canyon Forest Reserve in Arizona.
X4: NOTESDemonstrates the paramount importance of utilitarian considerations in the public management of natural resources.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 30, Chap. 377, pp. 993-995.  "An Act To set aside a portion of certain lands in the State of Washington, now known as the Pacific Forest Reserve, as a public park, to be known as the Mount Ranier National Park."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1899 03 02
X3: SUMMARY Establishes Mount Rainier National Park.  Includes a provision revoking a previous land grant within the proposed park to the Northern Pacific Railroad, in compensation for which the Railroad is to receive a comparable tract of land of its choice elsewhere.
X4: NOTESThe provision concerning the Northern Pacific was in fact extremely favorable to the railroad, permitting it to exchange lands which were actually worthless for lumbering for unsurveyed lands elsewhere (in southwestern Washington) which contained some of the finest virgin forest remaining in the Northwest.  Some contemporary critics consequently charged that the creation of the park was merely a ruse devised to aid the railroad by its friends in Congress.  Much of the finest timberlands which the railroad obtained by this exchange were sold in 1900 to the Weyerhaeuser Timber Company, solidifying its dominance of the region's lumber industry.  (For further details, see Roy E. Appleman, "Timber Empire from the Public Domain," Mississippi Valley Historical Review, Vol. XXXVI, No. 2 [September 1939], pp. 193-208.)

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 30, Chap. 417, pp. 1012-1013.  "An Act For the protection of birds, preservation of game, and for the prevention of its sale during certain closed seasons in the District of Columbia."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia  Washington Government Printing Office 1899 03 03
X3: SUMMARY Stipulates regulations for the hunting and sale of game and birds in the District of Columbia.
X4: NOTESThe existence of these sorts of regulations indicates recognition of the need for bird and game conservation.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 30, Chap. 429, Title I, Chapter Twelve, pp. 1279-81.  "Protection of Fur-Bearing Animals and Salmon."  Sub-section of "An Act To define and punish crimes in the District of Alaska and to provide a code of criminal procedure for said district."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1899 03 03
X3: SUMMARY Establishes a criminal code regarding the harvesting of fur-bearing animals and salmon in Alaska, including provisions barring the killing of "any otter, mink, marten, sable, or fur seal, or other fur-bearing animal within the limits of Alaska Territory, or in the waters thereof;" establishing strict regulations for the killing of fur seals elsewhere in the region; outlawing interference with salmon spawning; and regulating salmon fishing.
X4: NOTESEstablishes strict legal protection for certain categories of Alaskan wildlife, reflecting their value as an economic resource.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 31, Chap. 372, pp. 790-91.  "An Act Relating to rights of way through certain parks, reservations, and other public lands." [H.R. 11973]
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1901 02 15
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior "to permit the use of rights of way through the public lands, forest and other reservations of the United States, and the Yosemite, Sequoia, and General Grant national parks, California" for electrical power, telephone and telegraph communication, and irrigation and water supply.
X4: NOTESKnown as the Right of Way Act.  Demonstrates the complex and ambiguous understanding of national parks and forest reserves in this era, in which utilitarian concerns often assumed paramount importance even in areas set aside for aesthetic and recreational reasons.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 31, Chap. 553, pp. 187-189.  "An Act To enlarge the powers of the Department of Agriculture, prohibit the transportation by interstate commerce of game killed in violation of local laws, and for other purposes." [H.R. 6634; Public Act No. 119]
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1900 05 25
X3: SUMMARY Purpose of the Act is "to aid in the restoration of such birds in those parts of the United States adapted thereto where the same have become scarce or extinct."  Enlarges the powers of the Department of Agriculture "so as to include the preservation, distribution, introduction, and restoration of game birds and other wild birds," and prohibits the interstate shipment of any wild animals or birds killed in violation of state laws.
X4: NOTESKnown as the Lacey Act in honor of its chief legislative sponsor, preservationist Representative John F. Lacey of Iowa.  A landmark piece of preservation legislation; the first national legislation for wildlife protection.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 31, Resolution No. 10, pp. 711-12.  "Joint Resolution Providing for the acquisition of certain lands in the State of California." [H.J.R. 170; Public Resolution No. 10]
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1900 03 08
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to initiate purchase of two groves of Sequoia gigantea in Calaveras County, California, "with sufficient adjacent lands for their preservation, management, and control," on the grounds that the current private owners plan to cut these trees and their destruction "would be an irredeemable loss to science, and the loss of one of the marked wonders of the world."
X4: NOTESPreservation of a natural resource on scientific and aesthetic rather than utilitarian grounds.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 32, Part 1, Chap. 1037, pp. 327-28.  "An Act For the protection of game in Alaska, and for other purposes." Public Act No. 147
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1902 06 07
X3: SUMMARY  Protects certain game animals and birds in Alaska by limiting hunting.
X4: NOTESKnown as the Alaska Game Act.  An important piece of wildlife-protection legislation; its provisions were strengthened by the Act for the Protection of Game in Alaska of 1908 (35 Stat. 102).

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 32, Part 1, Chap. 1093, pp. 388-90.  "An Act Appropriating the receipts from the sale and disposal of public lands in certain States and Territories to the construction of irrigation works for the reclamation of arid lands." [S. 3057]; Public Act No. 161
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1902 06 17
X3: SUMMARY Devotes all money received henceforth from the sale of public lands in Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Kansas, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Oregon, South Dakota, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming to a revolving "reclamation fund" for the development and management of irrigation projects in the "arid and semiarid lands in the said States and Territories," which will be reimbursed by settlers' mandatory repayment of the construction costs of the irrigation projects.
X4: NOTESKnown as the Newlands Reclamation Act in honor of its chief legislative sponsor, Representative Francis G. Newlands of Nevada; sometimes referred to in subsequent legislation as "the national irrigation law" or "the national reclamation act."  The most important piece of legislation in the Federally-sponsored effort to create agricultural land by the management of water resources, this Act received overwhelming support from major Western business and political interests as it committed the Federal government to support and, ultimately, control of the massive irrigation projects which determined much of the subsequent environmental, political, economic, and social history of the arid West.  Though not usually considered an aspect of conservation in our own day, irrigation was understood to be an integral part of the utilitarian dimension of the conservation movement at the turn of the century.  The bureaucratic entity which administered the terms of this Act was the Reclamation Service, initially formed within the Geological Survey of the Department of the Interior under the leadership of Frederick Newell; it became an independent agency in 1907, and in 1923 was renamed the Bureau of Reclamation.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 32, Part 1, Chap. 63, pp. 765-66.  "An Act To set apart certain lands in the State of South Dakota as a public park, to be known as the Wind Cave National Park." Public Act No. 16
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1903 01 09
X3: SUMMARY Establishes Wind Cave National Park.
X4: NOTESWind Cave contained notable underground caverns; however, its designation as a national park broke the precedent of awarding national park status for purposes of scenic preservation only to spectacular sites.  The establishment of this park may also be seen as an indication of the growing prestige of national parks, which led residents of regions outside the prototypically scenic West to wish to see parks established in their own locales also.

The Reserve included the water supply for the city of Portland, and part of the intent of the Act was to protect this supply; the connection exemplifies the often-close link between timber and water resource management in the development of conservation policy.

X4: NOTESKnown as the Transfer Act.  Placed the forest reserves under the jurisdiction of Gifford Pinchot's bureau, in accordance with the recommendations of the American Forest Congress of 1905; the change permitted Pinchot to implement his ambitious program of scientific forest management.

X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1907 03 04
X3: SUMMARY Forest reserves are re-named national forests; their further creation or enlargement in Oregon, Washington, Idaho, Montana, Colorado, or Wyoming is forbidden except by act of Congress.
X4: NOTESDemonstrates the tension between Congress and members of the Roosevelt administration over the direction of conservation policy.  Unwilling to pocket-veto the entire appropriations act, Roosevelt permitted Gifford Pinchot and his staff to identify some 16,000,000 acres of forest in the six states in question, which the President then designated as new national forest lands, between Congress's passage of the bill on February 25 and its signing by the President on March 4.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Chap. 3060, p. 225.  "An Act For the preservation of American antiquities." S. 4698, Public Act No. 209
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 06 08
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes the President "to declare by public proclamation historic landmarks, historic and prehistoric structures, and other objects of historic or scientific interest that are situated upon the lands owned or controlled by the Government of the United States to be national monuments, and may reserve as a part thereof parcels of land;" forbids unauthorized injury of objects of antiquity on Government lands; and authorizes the granting of Federal permits for the study of objects of antiquity on such lands.
X4: NOTESKnown as the American Antiquities Act.  Demonstrates the fundamental connection between cultural conservation and the conservation of natural resources; provided the basis for preservation of places of scientific value on Presidential initiative alone.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Chap. 3074, pp. 233-34.  "An Act To provide for the entry of Agricultural lands within forest reserves." H.R. 17576; Public Act No. 220
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 06 11
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes the Secretary of Agriculture to give the Secretary of the Interior a list of lands in forest reserves "which are chiefly valuable for agriculture, and which, in his opinion, may be occupied for agricultural purposes without injury to the forest reserves," so that they may be opened for homesteading; these provisions will not apply to some forest reserves in California.
X4: NOTESKnown as the Forest Homestead Act.  Demonstrates the utilitarian and multi-purpose understanding of forest reserves in this era, the continuing importance of agriculture in the formation of public policy, and the continuing debate over the use of publicly-held lands in the West.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Chap. 3288, p. 259.  "An Act To extend the irrigation Act to the State of Texas." H.R. 14184; Public Act No. 225
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 06 12
X3: SUMMARY Extends the provisions of the Newlands Reclamation Act (32 Stat. 388) to the entire State of Texas.
X4: NOTESPublished 1907.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Chap. 3299, pp. 263-64.  "An Act To prohibit aliens from fishing in the waters of Alaska." S. 267; Public Act No. 228
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 06 14
X3: SUMMARY Forbids aliens from fishing in any Alaskan waters "except with rod, spear, or gaff," or when employed by American individuals or companies.
X4: NOTESAn attempt to ensure exclusively American profit from valuable natural resources.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Chap. 3442, pp. 313-14.  "An Act To regulate the landing, delivery, cure, and sale of sponges." S. 4806; Public Act No. 250
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 06 20
X3: SUMMARY Regulates the harvesting and sale of Gulf of Mexico sponges.
X4: NOTESManagement of an economically valuable marine resource.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Chap. 3547, pp. 478-81.  "An Act For the protection and regulation of the fisheries of Alaska." H.R. 13543; Public Act No. 298
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 06 26
X3: SUMMARY Establishes detailed regulations to govern the fishing industry in Alaska, with particular attention to salmon fishing.
X4: NOTESMarine and riverine conservation regulations to ensure the continued viability of economically valuable resources.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Chap. 3555, pp. 517-18.  "An Act Granting lands to the State of Wisconsin for forestry purposes." S. 6462; Public Act No. 304
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 06 27
X3: SUMMARY Grants up to 20,000 acres of public land to the State of Wisconsin for use as a forest reserve.
X4: NOTESAn indication of the development of of scientific forestry as a significant aspect of public policy at the state as well as at the Federal level.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Chap. 3565, pp. 536-37.  "An Act To protect birds and their eggs in game and bird preserves." H.R. 13190; Public Act No. 314
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 06 28
X3: SUMMARY Outlaws the hunting, trapping, capture, willful disturbance, or killing of any bird or egg on any land legally set aside as a bird breeding ground.
X4: NOTESAn important step in wildlife protection at the national level.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Chap. 3593, p. 607.  "An Act For the protection of wild animals in the Grand Canyon Forest Reserve." S. 2732, Public Act No. 339
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 06 29
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes the President to designate areas in the Grand Canyon Forest Reserve as a protected breeding-ground for game animals, within which "hunting, trapping, killing, or capturing of game animals" would be forbidden.
X4: NOTESRoosevelt acted on this authorization in his Proclamations of November 28, 1906 (34 Stat. 3263), and June 23, 1908 (35 Stat. 2192).

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Chap. 3607, pp. 616-17.  "An Act Creating the Mesa Verde National Park." H.R. 5998, Public Act No. 353
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 06 29
X3: SUMMARY Establishes Mesa Verde National Park, instructing the Secretary of the Interior to prescribe regulations "specifically for the preservation from injury or spoliation of the ruins and other works and relics of prehistoric or primitive man within said park," and authorizing the Secretary to permit legitimate archeological investigations of the ruins by properly qualified and institutionally affiliated persons.
X4: NOTESLike the American Antiquities Act, this Act demonstrates the fundamental connection between cultural conservation and the conservation of natural resources.  The decision to protect some of the works of the nation's "primitive" inhabitants through the creation of a national park reflects the degree to which Native peoples were repeatedly associated with the American land and wilderness in the conservation-related literature of white Americans in this era.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Chap. 3621, pp. 626-28.  "An Act For the control and regulation of the waters of Niagara River, for the preservation of Niagara Falls, and for other purposes." H.R. 18024; Public Act No. 367
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 06 29
X3: SUMMARY Prohibits the diversion of water from Niagara River or its tributaries in the State of New York, except as explicitly authorized by the Secretary of War under specified terms and conditions for up to three years from the date of this Act, and requests the President to open treaty negotiations with Great Britain (acting for Canada) "for such regulation and control of the waters of Niagara River and its tributaries as will preserve the scenic grandeur of Niagara Falls and of the rapids in said river."
X4: NOTESKnown as the Burton Act.  An important act of landscape preservation: it makes diversion of water for power supplies subordinate to preservation of one of the nation's scenic marvels.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Chap. 3932, pp. 808-09.  "An Act To prohibit the killing of wild birds and animals in the District of Columbia." H.R. 13193; Public Act No. 401
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 06 30
X3: SUMMARY Outlaws the killing of all wild birds except for English sparrows, or when killing is for the prevention of crop or poultry destruction, or for hunting along rivers; limits the hunting of wild animals to circumstances of written permission from District authorities; and outlaws the disturbing of waterfowl by boats other than rowboats, in the District of Columbia.
X4: NOTESAnother example of an essentially local law which reflects increasing public concern for wildlife conservation.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Chap. 950, pp. 62-63.  "An Act To extend the provisions of the homestead laws to certain lands in the Yellowstone Forest Reserve." H.R. 13673; Public Act No. 46
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 03 15
X3: SUMMARY Permits homesteading on a portion of the Yellowstone Forest Reserve, Wyoming and Montana.
X4: NOTESAn example of the mixed-use and utilitarian conception of forest reserves in this era.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Resolution No. 27, pp. 831-32.  "Joint Resolution Accepting the recession by the State of California of the Yosemite Valley Grant and the Mariposa Big Tree Grove, and including the same, together with fractional sections five and six, township five south, range twenty-two east, Mount Diablo meridian, California, within the metes and bounds of the Yosemite National Park, and changing the boundaries thereof." H.J.R. 118; Public Resolution No. 27
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 06 11
X3: SUMMARY Ratifies the recession of the Yosemite Valley Grant and the Mariposa Big Tree Grove from the State of California to the Federal government as part of Yosemite National Park, and reconfigures the boundaries of the Park and of the adjacent Sierra Forest Reserve accordingly.
X4: NOTESIn 1864, these lands had been granted from the Federal government to the State of California (13 Stat. 325); see also the Joint Resolution of March 3, 1905 (33 Stat. 1286), which  appropriated funds for the return of these lands from California.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Resolution No. 42, p. 837.  "Joint Resolution Directing that the Sulphur Springs Reservation be named and hereafter called the Platt National Park.'" S.J.R. 69; Public Resolution No. 42
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 06 29
X3: SUMMARY Designates the Sulphur Springs Reservation, an Indian reservation in Oklahoma, as Platt National Park.
X4: NOTESThe new park contained medicinal springs.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 34, Part 1, Resolution No. 9, p. 824.  "Joint Resolution For a report, and so forth, upon the preservation of Niagara Falls." H.J.R. 83; Public Resolution No. 9
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1906 03 15
X3: SUMMARY Calls on the American representatives to an international commission to report to Congress their recommendations for preventing further depletion of Niagara Falls, and to work with Canadian commissioners "to exert... all possible efforts for the preservation of the said Niagara Falls in their natural condition."
X4: NOTESReflects Congressional concern over the preservation of one of the nation's great scenic wonders, which was largely the result of the campaign to protect Niagara orchestrated by J. Horace McFarland, of the American Civic Association, joined by other private conservation organizations such as the Sierra Club and the Appalachian Mountain Club.  The outcome was a treaty (signed in 1909) between the U.S. and Great Britain, acting for Canada, which ultimately limited the total amount of water diverted from the Falls to 56,000 cubic feet per second, a limitation which remained in effect until 1950.

X3: SUMMARY Establishes Muir Woods National Monument, California, on land donated by William and Elizabeth Thatcher Kent, on the grounds that "an extensive growth of redwood trees (Sequoia sempervirens) embraced in said land is of extraordinary scientific interest and importance because of the primeval character of the forest in which it is located, and of the character, age and size of the trees."
X4: NOTESAt the Kents' request, this national monument was named in honor of John Muir.  William Kent himself afterwards served as a Representative from California in Congress, where he disagreed with Muir on the fate of Hetch Hetchy Valley, but later introduced the legislation establishing the National Park Service in 1916 (39 Stat. 535).

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 36, Part 1, Chap. 183, pp. 326-28.  "An Act To protect the seal fisheries of Alaska, and for other purposes." S. 7942; Public Act No. 146
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1910 04 21
X3: SUMMARY Amends the criminal code for Alaska to permit the Secretary of Commerce and Labor to regulate the killing of seals and other fur-bearing animals, and authorizes the killing of fur seals on the Pribilof Islands by "officers, agents, or employees of the United States appointed by the Secretary of Commerce and Labor, and by the natives of the Pribilof Islands" under government supervision.
X4: NOTESReflects continued Congressional concern for the protection of an economically valuable wildlife resource, and the forceful lobbying of wildlife preservationist William Temple Hornaday, director of the New York Zoological Society, who had become acutely concerned to preserve the fur seal herds as completely as possible from further depredation, and almost single-handedly made the case to Congress for timely protection.  This bill did not inhibit hunting to the extent that Hornaday had desired, however, and his increasingly public and acrimonious criticism of Federal policy eventually led to more restrictive legislation (see 37 Stat. 499).

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 36, Part 1, Chap. 186, pp. 961-63.  "An Act To enable any State to cooperate with any other State or States, or with the United States, for the protection of the watersheds of navigable streams, and to appoint a commission for the acquisition of lands for the purpose of conserving the navigability of navigable rivers." H.R. 11798, Public Act. No. 435
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1911 03 01
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes cooperative agreements between states for conserving their forests and water supply; appropriates funds for the Secretary of Agriculture to use for cooperative efforts with states for fire protection of forested watersheds of navigable streams; appoints a National Forest Reservation Commission, to consist of the Secretaries of War, Interior, and Agriculture and two members each of the House and Senate, to assist the Secretary of Agriculture in acquiring "such lands as in his judgment may be necessary to the regulation of the flow of navigable streams;" and appropriates funds until 1915 for the purpose of such  acquisitions.
X4: NOTESKnown as the Weeks Act.  A major piece of conservation legislation demonstrating the close connection between issues of watershed protection and issues of forestry in the formation of conservation policy, and providing the statutory basis for the creation of additional national forests, especially in the East.

X3: SUMMARY Authorizes and appropriates funds for the establishment of a marine biological research station on the Florida Gulf Coast, to be available for the use of faculty and students "of the several land-grant, agricultural, and mechanical colleges of the United States."

X4: NOTESThe Act's provision for reclamation projects suggests the heterogeneous vision of national parks in this era.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 36, Part 1, Chap. 359, p. 593.  "An Act To prevent the dumping of refuse materials in Lake Michigan at or near Chicago." H.R. 18700; Public Act No. 245
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1910 06 23

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 36, Part 1, Chap. 421, pp. 847-48.  "An Act To authorize the President of the United States to make withdrawals of public lands in certain cases." H.R. 24070, Public Act No. 303
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1910 06 25
X3: SUMMARY The President "may, at any time in his discretion, temporarily withdraw from settlement, location, sale, or entry any of the public lands of the United States... and reserve the same for water-power sites, irrigation, classification of lands, or other public purposes...," and such withdrawals are to remain in force "until revoked by him or by an Act of Congress."  However, no forest reserves are to be created or expanded in Oregon, Washington, Idaho, Montana, Colorado, or Wyoming "except by Act of Congress," and any lands withdrawn under this Act "shall at all times be open to exploration, discovery, occupation, and purchase, under the mining laws of the United States, so far as the same apply to minerals other than coal, oil, gas, and phosphates."
X4: NOTESAmended by an Act of August 24, 1912 (37 Stat. 497) to make such lands open to mining of "metalliferous minerals," and to extend the provision against new national forests to California.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 36, Part 1, Resolution No. 3, pp. 871-72.  "Joint Resolution Authorizing an investigation of the Department of the Interior and its several bureaus, officers, and employees, and of the Bureau of Forestry, in the Department of Agriculture, and its officers and employees." H.J. Res. 103; Public Resolution No. 9
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1910 01 19
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes an investigation by a joint committee of both Houses of Congress into the Department of the Interior and the Bureau of Forestry, including public hearings, and requires that the results of the investigation be compiled in a report to Congress.
X4: NOTESThis investigation developed out of the acrimonious public breach between Forest Service chief Gifford Pinchot and Secretary of the Interior Richard A. Ballinger.  Though heavily politicized, the controversy had its roots in basic philosophical disagreements over the conduct of conservation policy: fundamentally, Ballinger wished to facilitate the development of natural resources by private capital in what he believed to be as fair a manner as possible, while Pinchot was primarily concerned with protecting public resources from private greed and shortsightedness through rational public ownership and management.  Smoldering conflict between the two men broke into the open when Pinchot accused Ballinger on dubious evidence of official impropriety in the handling of some coal claims in Alaska; though President Taft decided that the charges were unfounded and initially hoped to retain both men in the Administration, the accusations were made public in sensational form.  The subsequent uproar obliged Taft to fire Pinchot and to demarcate his differences with his predecessor Theodore Roosevelt on conservation policy, and led Congress to pass this Resolution.  Congress's investigation exonerated Ballinger, but Pinchot won the public relations war: the controversy severely damaged both Ballinger's reputation (he resigned in 1911) and the Taft Administration's own in the public eye.  (For a full history of this controversy, and interpretation which is particularly sympathetic to Ballinger, see James L. Penick, Jr., Progressive Politics and Conservation: The Ballinger-Pinchot Affair [Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1968].)

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 37, Part 1, Chap. 145, pp. 846-48.  "Bureau of Biological Survey."  Sub-section of "An Act Making appropriations for the Department of Agriculture for the fiscal year ending June thirtieth, nineteen hundred and fourteen." H.R. 28283, Public Act No. 430
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1913 03 04
X3: SUMMARY Includes provisions placing all "migratory and insectivorous birds which in their northern and southern migrations pass through or do not remain permanently the entire year within the borders of any State or Territory" under the "custody and protection of the Government of the United States," with their protection and hunting seasons to be regulated by the Department of Agriculture.
X4: NOTESKnown as the Migratory Bird Act or Weeks-McLean Act.  An important milestone in bird protection, superseded by the Migratory Bird Treaty Act of 1918 (40 Stat. 755).

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 37, Part 1, Chap. 264, p. 241.  "An Act To authorize the exchange of certain lands with the State of Michigan." H.R. 4012; Public Act No. 247
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1912 07 31
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes the exchange of public lands in Michigan with the State of Michigan in return for lands there which the Secretary of Agriculture wishes to include in a national forest.
X4: NOTESRepresents cooperation between Congress and the Executive on the creation of a new national forest, and points to the uneasy balance between the states and the Federal government in the allocation of control over public lands and resources.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 37, Part 1, Chap. 328, p. 324.  "An Act Granting unsurveyed and unattached islands to the State of Wisconsin for forestry purposes." H.R. 13417; Public Act No. 283
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1912 08 22
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes the granting of certain islands on lakes in public lands in the State of Wisconsin to the state as additions to the state's forest reserves.
X4: NOTESAn indication of the development of scientific forestry as a significant aspect of public policy at the state as well as at the Federal level.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 37, Part 1, Chap. 369, p. 497.  "An Act To amend section two of an Act to authorize the President of the United States to make withdrawals of public lands in certain cases, approved June twenty-fifth, nineteen hundred and ten." S. 5679, Public Act No. 316
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1912 08 24
X3: SUMMARY Amends the Act of June 25, 1910 (36 Stat. 847) to make the lands withdrawn open to mining of "metalliferous minerals," and adds California to the list of states within which new or additional forest reserve lands (national forests) are forbidden.
X4: NOTES36 Stat. 847 had authorized the President to withdraw public lands from entry for specified purposes.  See also the portion of the Agricultural Appropriations Act passed in 1907 which forbids Presidential withdrawal of lands for forestry purposes in specified states (34 Stat. 1269).

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 37, Part 1, Chap. 373, pp. 499-502.  "An Act To give effect to the convention between the Governments of the United States, Great Britain, Japan, and Russia for the preservation and protection of the fur seals and sea otter which frequent the waters of the north Pacific Ocean, concluded at Washington July seventh, nineteen hundred and eleven." H.R. 16571; Public Act No. 320
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1912 08 24
X3: SUMMARY Enacts the convention concluded among representatives of the United States, Great Britain, Japan, and Russia on July 7, 1911, for the protection of fur seals and sea otters in the North Pacific, by outlawing the killing of fur seals and sea otters in these waters by any Americans except Alaskan Natives, and authorizes the use of naval patrols to enforce these regulations; and suspends most fur seal killing in Alaska for a period of five years.
X4: NOTESA further international effort to protect an economically valuable and internationally contested wildlife resource, this Act was also the final result of a public campaign by wildlife preservationist William Temple Hornaday, director of the New York Zoological Society, to protect fur seals both from hunters and from what he believed to be the mismanagement of Federal officials, notably Secretary of Commerce and Labor Charles Nagel, whose department had jurisdiction over seal hunting in accordance with the Act of April 21, 1910 (36 Stat. 326).

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 37, Part 1, Chap. 74, pp. 80-81.  "An Act To authorize the Secretary of the Interior to secure for the United States title to patented lands in the Yosemite National Park, and for other purposes." S. 5718; Public Act No. 117
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1912 04 09
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to obtain title to any or all privately-held lands within the area of Yosemite National Park in exchange for timber from the park, and to exchange timber growing away from the park's roads for privately-held stands of timber near the roads.
X4: NOTESDemonstrates concern for scenic resources, and active management of them, and points to the ongoing problem of reconciling the needs of national parks with local property rights.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 38, Part 1, Chap. 16, pp. 146-52.  "Schedule N--Sundries."  Sub-section of "An Act To reduce tariff duties and to provide revenue for the Government, and for other purposes." H.R. 3321, Public Act No. 16
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1913 10 03
X3: SUMMARY This sub-section of a much longer tariff bill contains a paragraph (no. 347, on p. 148) that prohibits "the importation of aigrettes, egret plumes or so-called osprey plumes, and the feathers, quills, heads, wings, tails, skins, or parts of skins, of wild birds, either raw or manufactured, and not for scientific or educational purposes."
X4: NOTESThis measure effectively put an end to U.S. participation in the extensively destructive international trade in wild bird feathers for women's hats.  Drafted by wildlife preservationist William Temple Hornaday, it represented the culmination of a lengthy campaign of public-opinion pressure and legislative lobbying by many conservationists, both men and women, among whom Hornaday and the National Association of Audubon Societies, led by T. Gilbert Pearson, were particularly responsible for this final victory.
