X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 38, Part 1, Chap. 264, pp. 699-701.  "An Act To accept the cession by the State of Montana of exclusive jurisdiction over the lands embraced within the Glacier National Park, and for other purposes." S. 654; Public Act No. 177
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1914 08 22
X3: SUMMARY Accepts the State of Montana's cession of exclusive jurisdiction over lands within Glacier National Park; prohibits hunting in the Park, except as necessary to prevent human injury or loss of life; prohibits fishing except by "hook and line" in certain seasons; directs the Secretary of the Interior to establish regulations to protect the Park's timber, mineral deposits, "natural curiosities, or wonderful objects... and for the protection of the animals and birds... and to prevent their being frightened or driven from the park;" and authorizes the judicial appointment of a Commissioner to reside in the park and adjudicate and prosecute violations of the park's laws.
X4: NOTESThis Act, like the similar Acts for Mt. Rainier, Crater Lake, Yosemite, Sequoia, and General Grant National Parks (39 Stat. 243, 39 Stat. 521, and 41 Stat. 731), includes extensive regulations designed to facilitate prosecution of hunters and other despoilers of the park's resources and wildlife, suggesting conflict between hunters and park management in the national parks in this era.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 38, Part 1, Chap. 39, p. 308.  "An Act For the protection of the water supply of the city of Baker, a municipal corporation of the State of Oregon." S. 3206; Public Act No. 71
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1914 03 14
X3: SUMMARY Dedicates a portion of the public lands in Whitman National Forest, Oregon, to the use of the city of Baker for the construction and maintenance of a municipal water-supply system.
X4: NOTESAnother demonstration of the close connection between forestry and the management of water resources in Federal conservation thought and policy in this era.  Note, however, that it was a similar dedication of a portion of Yosemite National Park to San Francisco's water supply that provoked the bitter Hetch Hetchy controversy of c.1906-1913.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 38, Part 1, Chap. 4, pp. 242-51.  "An Act Granting to the city and county of San Francisco certain rights of way in, over, and through certain public lands, the Yosemite National Park, and Stanislaus National Forest, and certain lands in the Yosemite National Park, the Stanislaus National Forest, and the public lands in the State of California, and for other purposes." H.R. 7207; Public Act No. 41
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1913 12 19
X3: SUMMARY Grants the city and county of San Francisco rights of way through, certain lands in, and the use of certain resources in Yosemite National Park, Stanislaus National Forest, and certain public lands, in order to construct and maintain a municipal water and water-power supply system; these rights include the right to construct and operate a reservoir by damming Hetch Hetchy Valley in Yosemite National Park.
X4: NOTESKnown as the Raker Act, in honor of its chief sponsor, Congressman John E. Raker.  The most controversial piece of legislation in the history of American conservation before 1920: the culmination of a multi-year battle which bitterly split the conservation movement between those who saw the practical use of natural resources as conservationism's essential goal (utilitarian conservationists), and those who advocated the moral necessity of preserving wilderness and scenic areas even at the cost of forgoing the use of important natural resources (preservationists).  The preservationists, led by the pioneering Scottish-American wilderness philosopher John Muir (1838-1914), lost the battle in this case, but the controversy did much to bring conservation issues into the mainstream of American public consciousness, galvanized widespread popular support for the preservationist position and in particular for the movement to create the National Park Service, and crystallized the essential ideological division within the conservation movement for most of the rest of the century.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 38, Part 1, Chap. 88, pp. 376-77.  "An Act To consolidate certain forest lands in the Sierra National Forest, and Yosemite National Park, California." H.R. 13770; Public Act No. 99
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1914 05 13
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes the exchange of privately-held lands within Yosemite National Park and certain areas of the Sierra National Forest for other lands "of approximately equal value" in other portions of the Sierra National Forest, "for the purpose of preserving scenic features" and consolidating Federal forest lands.
X4: NOTESAn example of Congressional concern for scenic values, and of the ongoing problem of reconciling the needs of national parks and forests with local property rights.

X3: SUMMARY Authorizes the Commissioner of Fisheries to determine how best to ameliorate the depredations committed on fisheries by "dogfish and other predacious fishes and aquatic animals," preferably by finding an economic use for the predators when taken, and appropriates up to $25,000 for the purpose.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 39, Part 1, Chap. 164, p. 1122.  "An Act To authorize an exchange of lands with owners of private holdings within the Glacier National Park." S. 778; Public Act No. 382
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1917 03 03
X3: SUMMARY Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to obtain title to privately-held lands within a specified area of Glacier National Park in exchange for timber from the park, in order to preserve intact "the natural forest along the roads in the scenic portions of the park."
X4: NOTESDemonstrates concern for scenic resources, and active management of them, and points to the ongoing problem of reconciling the needs of national parks with local property rights.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 39, Part 1, Chap. 197, pp. 243-46.  "An Act To accept the cession by the State of Washington of exclusive jurisdiction over the lands embraced within the Mount Rainier National Park, and for other purposes." S. 3928; Public Act No. 124
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1916 06 30
X3: SUMMARY Accepts the State of Washington's cession of exclusive jurisdiction over lands within Mount Rainier National Park; prohibits hunting in the Park, except as necessary to prevent human injury or loss of life; prohibits fishing except by "hook and line" in certain seasons; directs the Secretary of the Interior to establish regulations to protect the Park's timber, mineral deposits, "natural curiosities, or wonderful objects... and for the protection of the animals and birds... and to prevent their being frightened or driven from the park;" and authorizes the judicial appointment of a Commissioner to reside in the park and adjudicate and prosecute violations of the park's laws.
X4: NOTESThis Act, like the similar Acts for Glacier, Crater Lake, Yosemite, Sequoia, and General Grant National Parks (38 Stat. 699, 39 Stat. 521, and 41 Stat. 731), includes extensive regulations designed to facilitate prosecution of hunters and other despoilers of the park's resources and wildlife, suggesting conflict between hunters and park management in the national parks in this era.

X3: SUMMARY Establishes Hawaii National Park on the islands of Hawaii and Maui in the Territory of Hawaii.
X4: NOTESThe consolidation of this park, by the acquisition of all privately held lands and rights of way within the park by the Governor of Hawaii on behalf of the Territory, was authorized by an Act of Congress of February 27, 1920 (41 Stat. 452).

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 39, Part 1, Chap. 302, pp. 442-44.  "An Act To establish the Lassen Volcanic National Park in the Sierra Nevada Mountains in the State of California, and for other purposes." H.R. 348, Public Act No. 184

X4: NOTESThis Act, like the similar Acts for Glacier, Mount Rainier, Yosemite, Sequoia, and General Grant National Parks (38 Stat. 699, 39 Stat. 243, and 41 Stat. 731), includes extensive regulations designed to facilitate prosecution of hunters and other despoilers of the park's resources and wildlife, suggesting conflict between hunters and park management in the national parks in this era.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 39, Part 1, Chap. 408, pp. 535-36.  "An Act To establish a National Park Service, and for other purposes." H.R. 15522, Public Act No. 235
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1916 08 25
X3: SUMMARY Creates a National Park Service within the Department of the Interior, in order to "promote and regulate the use of the Federal areas known as national parks, monuments, and reservations... by such means and measures as conform to the fundamental purpose of the said parks, monument, and reservations, which purpose is to conserve the scenery and the natural and historic objects and the wild life therein and to provide for the enjoyment of the same in such manner and by such means as will leave them unimpaired for the enjoyment of future generations."  Timber cutting and killing of animals or plants in national parks is permitted to combat disease or depredation, and livestock grazing is permitted when it is not deemed detrimental, except in Yellowstone, where it is forbidden.
X4: NOTESLandmark legislation which defined the purpose of the national park system and established the means of its stewardship; the culmination of several years of public debate and campaigning led by preservationist conservationists such as J. Horace McFarland of the American Civic Association and Mrs. John Dickinson Sherman, chairman of the Conservation Committee of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.  The first Director of the National Park Service was Stephen T. Mather.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 40, Part 1, Chap. 128, pp. 755-57.  "An Act To give effect to the convention between the United States and Great Britain for the protection of migratory birds concluded at Washington, August sixteenth, nineteen hundred and sixteen, and for other purposes." S. 1553, Public Act No. 186
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1918 07 03
X3: SUMMARY This Act is to be known as the Migratory Bird Treaty Act.  Implements the 1916 convention between the U.S. and Great Britain for the protection of migratory birds, including their nests and eggs; authorizes the Secretary of Agriculture to oversee enforcement of the convention by regulating hunting, sale, transport, and export of such birds, and prosecuting violators of this Act; prohibits shipments of migratory birds in violation of state or Canadian laws.
X4: NOTESGreat Britain had acted for Canada in establishing the 1916 convention, which is printed in 39 Stat. 1702.  This major piece of international wildlife protection legislation superseded the 1913 Migratory Bird Act (Weeks-McLean Act; 37 Stat. 846).

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 40, Part 1, Chap. 44, pp. 1175-78.  "An Act To establish the Grand Canyon National Park in the State of Arizona." S. 390, Public Act No. 277

X3: SUMMARY Establishes Grand Canyon National Park, superseding Grand Canyon National Monument and incorporating a portion of the Grand Canyon National Game Preserve. X4: NOTESPublished 1919.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 40, Part 1, Chap. 76, pp. 1206-09.  "An Act Granting to the city of San Diego certain lands in the Cleveland National Forest and the Capitan Grande Indian Reservation for dam and reservoir purposes for the conservation of water, and for other purposes." S. 3646; Public Act No. 306
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1919 02 28
X3: SUMMARY Dedicates a portion of the Cleveland National Forest, California, and the Capitan Grande Indian Reservation to the use of the city of San Diego "for dam and reservoir purposes for the conservation and storage of water" for use by city inhabitants.
X4: NOTESAnother demonstration of the close connection between forestry and the management of water resources in Federal conservation thought and policy in this era, and of the essentially utilitarian approach to forest management and Federal conservation policy generally.  Note, however, that it was a similar dedication of a portion of Yosemite National Park to San Francisco's water supply that provoked the bitter Hetch Hetchy controversy of c.1906-1913.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 40, Part 2, pp. 1855-56 and map preceding p. 1855.  "By the President of the United States of America.  A Proclamation."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1918 09 24
X3: SUMMARY Establishes the Katmai National Monument, Alaska, on the grounds that Mount Katmai, an active volcano, offers "a conspicuous object lesson in volcanism to visitors interested in the operation of the great forces which have made and are still making America;" because the surrounding region contains "many other striking features of an active volcanic belt produced so recently that they are still in the formative stage;" and because "this wonderland may become of popular scenic, as well as scientific, interest for generations to come, inasmuch as all its phenomena exist upon a scale of great magnitude, arousing emotions of wonder at the inspiring spectacles, thus affording inspiration to patriotism and to the study of nature."
X4: NOTESThe language of this Proclamation offers an especially clear example of the connection between national identity, patriotism and the aesthetics of nature which was an important theme in American culture in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, and which helped shape the early conservation movement, especially in its "preservationist" strand.

X3: SUMMARY Accepts the State of California's cession of exclusive jurisdiction over lands within Yosemite, Sequoia, and General Grant National Parks; prohibits hunting in the Parks, except as necessary to prevent human injury or loss of life; prohibits fishing except by "hook and line" in certain seasons; directs the Secretary of the Interior to establish regulations to protect the Parks' timber, mineral deposits, "natural curiosities or wonderful objects... and for the protection of the animals... and to prevent their being frightened or driven from the said parks;" and authorizes the judicial appointment of a Commissioner for Yosemite and a joint Commissioner for Sequoia and General Grant, to reside in the appropriate park and adjudicate and prosecute violations of the parks' laws.

X1: U.S. Statutes at Large, Vol. 41, Part 1, Chap. 285, pp. 1063-1077.  "An Act To create a Federal Power Commission; to provide for the improvement of navigation; the development of water power; the use of the public lands in relation thereto, and to repeal section 18 of the River and Harbor Appropriation Act, approved August 8, 1917, and for other purposes." H.R. 3184, Public Act No. 280
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1920 06 10
X3: SUMMARY To be known as the Federal Water Power Act.  Created a Federal Power Commission, consisting of the Secretary of War, the Secretary of the Interior, and the Secretary of Agriculture, with extensive authority over waterways and the construction and use of water power projects.
X4: NOTESDevelopment of water resources was still considered an appropriate aspect of conservation policy at this time, and this Act was the culmination of many years of public debate on how best to control and develop the use of this resource.  Note that the Act as written permitted the Commission to authorize water power development projects within national parks and monuments; however, an act amending this provision was passed on March 3, 1921 (41 Stat. 1353), which forbade such projects in national parks or monuments without specific authority of Congress.

X1: U.S., Statutes at Large, Vol. 25, Resolution No. 7, pp. 618-19.  "Joint resolution directing the Secretary of the Interior by means of the Director of the Geological Survey to investigate the practicability of constructing reservoirs for the storage of water in the arid region of the United States, and to report to Congress."
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1888 03 20
X3: SUMMARY Directs the Director of the Geological Survey to prepare a report to Congress through the Secretary of the Interior on the practicability of constructing water reservoirs in the "arid region," thus potentially opening up the region to agricultural productivity.
X4: NOTESSuggests the Federal government's increasing interest in the potential of large-scale irrigation projects in the West, which became an integral part of Progressive-era conservation policy.  The Survey's Director at this time was John Wesley Powell, who was vitally interested in the challenges of Western irrigation, though his understanding of them often diverged from that of Congress.

X3: SUMMARY Authorizes the expenditure of $20,000 for the recession of the Yosemite Valley Grant and the Mariposa Big Tree Grove from the State of California to the Federal government as part of Yosemite National Park.
X4: NOTESIn 1864, these lands had been granted from the Federal government to the State of California (13 Stat. 325); see also the Joint Resolution of June 11, 1906 (34 Stat. 831), which ratified the return of these lands and reconfigured Yosemite National Park accordingly.

X1: Withdrawal Act: Debates and Proceedings. Excerpted from the Congressional Record: Containing the Proceedings and Debates of the Sixty-First Congress, Second Session.  Volume XLV.  Pp. 4310, 4542, 4642-46, 5055-86, 5088-5103, 5109, 5248, 6880-81, 7375-76, 7457-79, 7538-64, 8042-60, 8150-77, 8234, 8508-09, 8569, 8580, 8667-73, 8699, 8712-13, 8786, 9118-19.
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1910
X3: SUMMARY Procedure and debate surrounding the passage of H.R. 24070, which eventually became "An Act To authorize the President of the United States to make withdrawals of public lands in certain cases"  (36 Stat. 847), in the Second Session of the 61st Congress.  Debate on this bill was lengthy and contentious; on one day debate went on for seven hours.  Among the major issues was the constitutional question of the respective powers of the executive and legislative branches and whether the act gave unprecedented powers to the former.  Some objected that the act "confers the powers of Congress on the President of the United States" and others maintained that the Supreme Court had already upheld the President's right to withdraw lands for the public good.  The question of the respective property rights of the Federal government, the states and territories, and private owners was debated, along with the history of the treatment of public lands from the beginning of the Republic.  Issues of different treatment of the western states and territories were raised.  There was extensive debate on the meaning of "conservation" and who among the members was or was not a "conservationist."  As with other conservation measures, there were cleavages along both party and regional lines, with spirited partisan debate on some issues and strong regional differences: western resentment over restrictions of water and mining rights and eastern reminders that conservation of resources was an eastern problem as well.  Strong differences remained to the last, with one representative declaring in the House debate on the Senate's amended version of the bill: "You will never have conservation under this bill (p. 8669)."
X4: NOTESWidely scattered pages selected from the complete record.  These pages report the introduction of the bill by Representative Pickett and its referral to the House Committee on the Public Lands, its report back to the House with amendment (H.R. Report 983), debate in the House, amendment and passage in the House, referral to the Senate Committee on Public Lands, report back to the Senate, report back again with amendment, debate in the Senate, amendment and passage in the Senate, motion to reconsider, reconsideration, amendment, debate, and passage in the Senate, House concurrance in Senate amendment, signing by the Speaker of the House and the Vice President, presentation to and approval by President Taft.

X1: Yellowstone Expedition of 1870.  Letter from the Secretary of War Communicating the Report of Lieutenant Gustavus C. Doane.  Senate Executive Document No. 51. From Index to the Executive Documents Printed by Order of the Senate of the United States for the Third Session of the Forty-First Congress.  1870-71.
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1871 03 03
X3: SUMMARY The Secretary of War transmits to the Committee on Territories Lt. Doane's report on the Yellowtone Expedition with accompanying letters from Generals Winfield Scott Hancock and William Tecumseh Sherman.  Doane escorted the surveyor general of Montana and others to the falls and lakes of the Yellowstone.  His report proceeds day by day for the 34 days of the expedition, giving the distance covered each day, the barometer and thermometer readings, and the elevation. For each day he describes the country traversed, sometimes in great detail and often lyrically.  He describes natural features as well as birds and animals, and people encountered, both Indians and frontiersmen.  Reference is made to a map and a complete record of observations accompanying the report, which are not part of the Senate document.
X4: NOTESPart of the legislative background for "An Act to set apart a certain Tract of Land lying near the Head-waters of the Yellowstone River as a public Park" (17 Stat. 32), which was adopted a year after the presentation of this report.

X1: Yellowstone Park Act: Debates and Proceedings. Excerpted from the Congressional Globe: Containing the Debates and Proceedings of the Second Session Forty-Second Congress; with an Appendix, Embracing the Laws Passed at that Session.  Pp. 159, 484, 520, 697, 1228, 1282, 1416.
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Office of the Congressional Globe 1872
X3: SUMMARY Procedure and debate surrounding the passage of S. 392, which eventually became "An Act to set apart a certain Tract of Land lying near the Head-waters of the Yellowstone River as a public park" (17 Stat. 32), in the Second Session of the 42nd Congress.  Debate centers on whether to forbid all hunting and fishing in the park or to allow subsistence taking for campers and on whether such a park is necessary at all, with eloquent statements on all sides.
X4: NOTESWidely-scattered pages selected from the complete record.  These pages report the introduction of the bill in the Senate by Senator Pomeroy, its referral to and from the Senate Committee on Public Lands, debate and passage in the Senate, passage in the House, and signing by President Grant.

X1: The Yellowstone Park.  House Report No. 26. From The Reports of Committees of the House of Representatives for the Second Session of the Forty-Second Congress.  1871-72.
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Government Printing Office 1872 02 27
X3: SUMMARY Report from the Committee on the Public Lands to accompany H.R. 764.  The bill proposes that a tract of land "about the sources of the Yellowstone and Missouri Rivers" be set "apart as a great national park or pleasure-ground."  The report points out that some people want "to fence in these rare wonders so as to charge visitors a fee, as is now done at Niagara Falls, for the sight of that which ought to be as free as the air or water. ... If this bill fails to become a law this session, the vandals who are now waiting to enter into this wonderland will, in a single season, despoil, beyond recovery, these remarkable curiosities which have required all the cunning skill of nature thousands of years to prepare."
X4: NOTESPart of the legislative background for "An Act to set apart a certain Tract of Land lying near the Head-waters of the Yellowstone River as a public Park" (17 Stat. 32).

X1: Yosemite Valley Grant Act: Debates and Proceedings. Excerpted from the Congressional Globe: Containing the Debates and Proceedings of the First Session of the Thirty-Eighth Congress.  Pp. 1310, 2299, 2300-2301, 2695, 3378, 3388-89, 3444.
X2: CREATED/PUBLISHED United States : District of Columbia : Washington Printed at the Congressional Globe Office 1864
X3: SUMMARY Procedure and debate surrounding the passage of S. 203, which became "An Act authorizing a Grant to the State of California of the Yo-Semite Valley,' and of the Land embracing the Mariposa Big Tree Grove'" (13 Stat. 325), in the First Session of the 38th Congress; the land was to be granted on condition that it become a public park.  Debate centers on the importance of preserving the extraordinary giant trees on this land, and on the unprecedented nature of such a grant.
X4: NOTESWidely-scattered pages selected from a much longer document.  These pages reflect the introduction of the bill in the Senate by Senator Conness, its referral to and from (without amendment) the Senate Committee on Public Lands, debate and passage in the Senate, introduction in the House and referral to and from the House Committee on Public Lands, passage in the House, signing by the Speaker of the House and President pro tempore of the Senate, and signing by President Lincoln.
